title: Martin Scorsese defends streaming The Irishman on Netflix
text:
Martin Scorsese is known for directing films like Taxi Driver and Goodfellas (Picture: AP)

Director Martin Scorsese has defended working with Netflix, which will stream his latest project straight into fans’ living rooms.

As a cinema icon, some critics feel Scorsese’s new film The Irishman should get a full cinematic release before going to streaming services, while others feel Netflix’s monopoly on the movie industry is getting too big.

However, Scorsese says he had to work with the company after other backers dropped out of funding the project, due to an inflated budget owing to expensive ‘de-ageing’ technology.

‘There’s no doubt that seeing a film with an audience is really important,’ he said.

‘There is a problem though: we have to make the film.’

Fair point.

Robert De Niro, Martin Scorsese and Al Pacino at the premiere of The Irishman yesterday (Picture: Getty Images)

He furthermore added: ‘We’ve run out of room, in a sense: there was no room for us to make this picture, for many reasons. [But] having the backing of a company that says you will have no interference, you can make the picture as you want – the trade-off being: it streams, with theatrical distribution prior to that.

‘I figure, that’s a chance we take, on this particular project.’

The director was speaking at a press conference for his new movie The Irishman at the London Film Festival when he made the comments.

He also renewed criticism of ‘Marvel-type pictures’ at the press conference, calling them ‘theme park films’.

Scorsese’s previous movies include Taxi Driver and Goodfellas. The Irishman, which stars Scorsese’s common collaborators Robert De Niro, Al Pacino and Joe Pesci, has so far won critical acclaim.

The film’s plot concerns former hitman called Frank Sheeran, who reflects on his career as he reaches old age.

The Irishman is released on Netflix on 7 November.
